reviews.text: Away from the hectic atmosphere of the city center this hotel is an excellent choice to discover Kathmandu. This former palace with very nice decorations inside gives a royal atmosphere. The staff was really friendly and helpful. Ther are some nice restaurants and cafes in walking distance. Though it is 15-20 min walk to Thamel it is not recommended. Taking a taxi is very cheap and convenient.

reviews.text: Stayed twice at the hotel, first time in older character rooms (although one of the rooms noisy from outside music), second time in newer renovated rooms, tidy, clean and comfortable. Staff friendly but gave me impression of waiting around for tips. Disappointed with buffet breakfast choice esp cereals. Recommended if looking for a unique hotel rather than the chains/groups.
reviews.title: Escape the chaos

reviews.text: It's really good hotel and in the good location and if I have a plan to Nepal again I will stay in this hotel again ..
reviews.title: The best hotel in Nepal ...

reviews.text: I stayed in Shanker Hotel on my first trip to Nepal! out side the hotel was really really busy ... I felt very safe to stay there though. The hotel itself was really clean! My favourite part of the day was sitting in the garden reading a book and ofcause a cup of coffee!! (I went there during winter time) so i felt just like lived in Europe!
reviews.title: Unique hotel

reviews.text: The staff in the hotel was really friendly too! i'm highly recommended this hotel!
reviews.title: Very Clean, Quiet, Safe and Warm

reviews.text: So glad we found this lovely hotel. The rooms were quite spacious and clean. The bathrooms were beautiful and equipped with plenty of hot water. Ahhh! Regular Kathmandu power outages were only noticeable for a few seconds, as the hotel's generator kicked in immediately. Heaters worked wonderfully. The pool and bar were a real treat, although it was too cold to take a dip. This hotel is in a nice quiet location, only about a 15 minute walk from the Thamel district.
reviews.title: Unique Hotel in busy Kathmandu!
Great location and place to relax!
reviews.text: We stayed at Hotel Shanker prior and post a 17 day trek up to EBC via Gokyo. The hotel looks amazing from the outside with a great pool and gardens. Its not super fancy on the inside. The rooms are very comfortable with standard amenities. The bathrooms have reliable hot water and good pressure. There are often only small "half windows" in the rooms which makes for not much light! I think we paid (via the tour company) ~US$100 per night and to be honest didn't look at many other options in the area. The staff are super helpful and friendly. The breakfast buffet we thought was great (don't have a nepal standard to compare to).

reviews.title: Better Value Elsewhere
reviews.text: The only issue is WiFi - Kathmandu pretty much has FREE WiFi where-ever you go! Even at cheap restaurants and cheaper hotels! We were stuck in Lukla for 5 days at even had free WiFI in all the guest houses and cafes there! I can't understand why Shanker charges so much! its ridiculous! We have found generally though that the higher the star rating of the hotel, the more basic things you have to cough up and pay for! We had delayed flights and missed connections due to bad weather and it is so much more convenient having free WiFI at the hotel to sort this stuff out - we subsequently just walked to Thamel and used free WiFi there!

reviews.title: A grand old palace
reviews.text: The other bonus is it is away from the hectic Thamel! which can be quite noisy at night. Its an easy 5-10minute walk into Thamel so not a big deal

reviews.title: Shanker looks better than it is
reviews.text: Overall - would stay at this hotel again, the WiFi factor would be the only reason I wouldn't.

reviews.title: Love the peace and quiet
reviews.text: I stayed at the Shanker for a wedding in Decemeber for 2 nights was less than impressed. Although I got a special rate for thr wedding I still found the value to be lacking and could not imagine paying full price. I stayed at Hotel Tibet prior to moving to the Shaker and preferred that hotel over the Shanker. I was on the 7th floor (Room 720) and the housekeeping staff would start talking outside my room befinning at 7am each morning and would continue all day long until I called reception to ask them to quiet down. The first day I heard a lot of noise outside my room so I opened the door and saw dog poop outside my room. I showed housekeeping who was standing outside by door chatting and they apologized at cleaned it up. But that put a horrible taste in my mouth. When I asked for room service or an Iron and the staff would come in my room and just start blatenly staring around and had to be ushered out the door.

description: Shanker Hotel Kathmandu is housed in a palace built at the turn of the 19th century by a Rana Maharajah with a penchant for French architecture, international cuisine and Eastern hospitality. It was converted into a hotel in 1964. The facade and traditions were kept intact but the interior was redesigned to give travelers the kind of comfort they'd expect of a world-class hotel. At Shanker Hotel Kathmandu, excellent service and superior facilities make for an unforgettable stay. Top features of the hotel include authentic heritage accommodation, beautiful poolside and garden area, professionally managed travel desk, concierge, restaurant, 24 Hour Room Service, banquet & convention center and historical neo-classical architecture. With an ideal location and facilities to match, Shanker Hotel Kathmandu hits the spot in many ways.Shanker Hotel Kathmandu has a long history and many events associated with it are part of the country's history itself. This palatial hotel, which was once owned by a Rana Maharajah of Nepal, is characterized by exquisite and authentic objects d'art, which enhances the beauty of the existing exterior. Nepal’s Late Queen Aishwarya and her sisters were be born in this palatial building. Besides this, it can truly be said to be a monument showcasing the European neo classical architectural style of the Rana regime in Nepal. We have been tenacious in clinging to our roots and by doing so; we stand out as a hotel with few equals, if at all in the historical city of Kathmandu.
